title: If your car is less than 90 days late can it be repossed?
question: Can a creditor pick your car up before it is 90 days late?
answers:
Mr. Kaufman's reply is a good review that a late payment can result in repossession, unless there is an actual agreement or understanding between the parties to accept a late payment by a certain due date, without repossessing the vehicle if the payment is timely made. Also, some creditors can arrange to put the upcoming or late payment at the end of the payment schedule, but these typically are confirmed with a written amendment to the installment agreement.

All contracts include the duty of both parties to act in good faith and deal fairly with the other party. That includes taking extreme actions (such as repossession, which is a costly process and can be very disruptive if this is the borrower's primary operating vehicle), unless the payment is seriously delinquent (more than a few days) or the vehicle's owner has expressed the intent to hide the vehicle or damage it or not insure it, as required by the agreement. There are other reasons, but 90 days late may justify repossession, unless the borrower has something in writing from the lender that permits the payments to be that late.

Please see my Avvo legal guide on consumer rights in California following repossession, which is linked below. You may want to consult with an experienced consumer attorney to further understand your rights and options to resolve this situation.
